page.title: 14Peat as fuel in Aith
page.content: Peats are the main fuel for fires in Shetland. They are dried pieces of peat moor. In late spring people start to cut their peats. First they cut the turf from the peat bank. This is called 'flaying'. Then they cut the peats with a tool called a 'tushkar'. They leave them to dry for about 2 weeks then set them up in little heaps called 'raisings' and leave them until they are dry through. The smaller peats, called 'clods', are usually bagged and the whole firing is taken home and either stored in a shed or built into a stack. Of the 75 houses in the block, 57 of them burn peats as their main fuel.
